mentions.context: GQL allows returning paths and lists as query answers.
GQL allows more complex path modes than described here.
GQL (Graph Query Language) is being developed as a new ISO standard for graph query languages to play the same role for graph databases as SQL plays for relational.
GQL, a standalone language for querying property graphs, that is expected to be published in late 2023 or early 2024.

GQL's rules are more involved, in that they allow TRAIL and ACYCLIC to be used inside patterns.

GQL has a facility to run subqueries through the CALL Q clause, the semantics of which is roughly as follows: for each binding µ in the input table, Q G ({µ}) is evaluated in a sub-process, and the resulting table is left-joined with the current working table.
GQL largely follows Cypher, which means its updates and transaction processing facilities need to be designed with care and subjected to the same research scrutiny as their relational counterpart.

At a high level, when evaluating a query, GQL keeps track of three things: (i) the working graph, which is the property graph we are using to match our patterns currently; (ii) the working table, that stores the information computed thus far; and (iii) the working record, which contains the tuple of the result we are currently using.

path patterns, which mimic regular path queries [29,30], but have additional features such as two-way navigation and conditioning; graph patterns, which generalize conjunctive two-way regular path queries [8] with the ability to return different types of paths; queries, which allow us to manipulate the results of graph patterns and combine their evaluation over different graphs in the database; and expressions and conditions, which allow filtering results obtained in previous three parts of GQL.
